results.title: Temperature
results.creator_credit: Ivo Burum, Victorian College of Agriculture and Horticulture and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Growing awareness: Factors in plant production”.
Temperature influences a plant’s growth, and plants have developed strategies to cope with extremes in temperature. In commercial plant production, statistical techniques are used to determine mean temperatures for different areas. Combining temperature and time, gives the concept of ‘heat summation’ measured in ‘degree days’. Crop Modelling uses a computer to combine data on light intensity, temperature and the rate of photosynthesis to determine optimum growing conditions.

results.title: Water
results.creator_credit: Martin Green, Victorian College of Agriculture and Horticulture and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Growing awareness: Factors in plant production”.
Water is a critical requirement for plant growth. This program examines different methods of watering commercial plants and how to measure water needs scientifically. Water moves from the roots throughout the plant, distributing nutrients and keeping the plant moist. This flow, called transpiration, is driven by diffusion, evaporation and capillary action. The plant uses osmosis to aid this process, and the importance of the Osmotic Gradient in how plants cope with drought, water-logging and salinity is discussed.

results.title: Light
results.creator_credit: Ivo Burum, Victorian College of Agriculture and Horticulture and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Growing awareness: Factors in plant production”.
Photosynthesis is the process by which a plant converts the energy from sunlight into sugars in specialised cells called chloroplasts. Respiration is the releasing of energy stored in sugars in the parts of the cells called mitochondria. The manipulation of light to simulate the natural habitat, shows how plant science can measure the relationship between light level and growth to determine optimum growing conditions.

results.title: Plants and people
results.creator_credit: Robin Wischusen, Victorian College of Agriculture and Horticulture and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Growing awareness: Factors in plant production”.
This program examines issues related to commercial farming considering the industry aspects of employment, economic value, the relationship between human dependence on plants and plant production, and the impact of technology. Examines the selective breeding used in the domestication of wheat and the use of genetic biology to provide a wider variety of product.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Robin Wischusen, Victorian College of Agriculture and Horticulture and ABC-TV (Australia)

results.title: Mathematical eye
results.creator_credit: Mike Cocker, Colin Nobbs, Adam Hart-Davis and Yorkshire Television
results.brief_description: A series of 20 minute programs designed to help students understand mathematical concepts and relate them to the real world. The programs use computer graphics and animation to assist students in visualising problems and solutions.

results.title: Fun and games
results.creator_credit: Colin Nobbs, Adam Hart-Davis and Yorkshire Television
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Mathematical eye”.
This program consists entirely of short mathematical puzzles that students answer using problem-solving techniques. It also presents games that can be played in the classroom and a basic introduction to algebra.

results.title: Paper engineering
results.creator_credit: Colin Nobbs, Adam Hart-Davis and Yorkshire Television
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Mathematical eye”.
This program provides an introduction to geometry. It includes useful demonstrations showing how manufacturers use geometric principles to design packaging and how a variety of geometric shapes can be made by folding paper. The distinction is made between two and three dimensional shapes and the mathematical link between geometric shapes is explored.

results.title: Information technology
results.creator_credit: Colin Nobbs, Adam Hart-Davis and Yorkshire Television
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Mathematical eye”.
Provides the student with an introduction to common computer-related terms such as databases and fields, and considers capturing and storing data in a usable form. Explains how computers sort data to produce useful output and briefly examines computer aided design and manufacture.

results.title: The Divine Mozart
results.creator_credit: Andrew Forrester, Jeremy Bugler, Channel Four and Fulmar
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “J’accuse”.
Nicholas Kenyon presents a critical look at the life and work of Mozart, exposing some of the myths that surround the famous composer. He rejects the notion of a saintly genius, who sacrificed himself for his art and died a pauper. When considered in the context of the historical period he lived in, Mozart emerges as a more “down to earth”, practical composer, who wrote music for money. The program includes comments from authorities in the music world and explores the reasons for Mozart’s popular appeal.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Andrew Forrester, Jeremy Bugler, Channel Four and Fulmar
